videos.title: The FPL Draft App That Changes Everything
videos.transcript: This is the FPL Draft Zone, your fantasy [music] team's best signing of the season. Hello and welcome to the FPL Draft Zone, a podcast all about draft FPL. I'm Dom Crofts. I hope you are well and today we have a very special episode for you because I am joined by David Gurgis who has created an app specifically for us FPL draft managers. It's called Fantasy Footy. It's available online at fantasyfooty.xyz. It's available on the app store if you are an Apple user and it's coming to Android very soon indeed. David, thanks so much for joining us. >> No, no, thank you for having me. We're going to get right into your app very shortly and show off all its amazing features. But before we do that, you are out in Canada. There is loads of fantasy sport for Canadians out there. Loads and loads of options and yet you have chosen to set up a fantasy draft app for FPL. How did your obsession with FPL draft come about? >> Yeah. No, so I've always been in uh involved in soccer uh or football as you guys call it there. Um, so I've been playing it, been watching it as a kid. I used to go to school, come back, have to put in a VHS tape, uh, to record the games that was whatever was playing for my dad. Uh, and used to watch them again after work. Um, so was always involved. Played soccer growing up as a kid. Played today. Um, and then just started playing fantasy sports or fantasy soccer specifically um, not too long ago, couple years ago. Started with the World Cup actually the previous one. Um, was killing it, doing amazing. Then I actually went to the World Cup, didn't do I forgot about the fantasy app and then came back and then just started with fantasy uh in the Premier League in the FPL and then started playing the uh fantasy draft a lot more and just got really into it. >> Got into it so much that you've decided to create an app for draft managers. How do you even go about doing something like that? >> Yeah. Yeah. No, so I'm a software developer uh in essence and so I was just looking at stats and trying to understand um more data from the league and our our like our league with my group of friends that we were playing with and just wanted to know who was unlucky, who was lucky, what if this would have happened if I had this trade, would I have won? Would I have would that have changed any outcome? And just started pulling data, writing scripts and going from there. Fantastic. Well, let's get into the app then. First of all, we're going to take you through some of the features. So, the appeal of this app for me is that it's got loads of little nuggets that you cannot get anywhere else. It has got your live head-to-head tracking, so you can follow your matches every game week live. Gives you full point breakdowns, projected points, automatic subs, indicators for players on track for bonus points, defensive contributions as well. It also does transfer activity insight, so you can track how active each manager has been in the transfer market, which players have moved around the most between teams. What I love, one of the features I really love is the manager performance stats. So, obviously you have the league table in FPL Draft, but you can create in your app league tables based on loads of other metrics. whose team has scored the most goals, who's got the most assists, bonus points, how that impacts the way the league table would look if that was the chief metric. And then you've got unlucky stats. Tell us what unlucky stats are. >> Yeah. So, that was one of the reasons why I made the app in the start was I wanted to calculate was I just unlucky in my I guess in my matchups. Did someone else have easier matchups? Were they always versing someone that was scoring less? Um, so basically the unlucky stats uh takes everyone's scores every week, calculates the median and sees if you scored above it or below it. And if you scored below the median and you uh or if you scored above the median and lost, then you're considered unlucky. And we do that every week to week. Um, and we keep track of it. And then we create a table where you can calculate who is the most lucky and unlucky person. Um, and you can see everyone's stats there. Um, so we have a a metric to measure how unlucky you were instead of someone just claiming to be the unluckiest. >> Absolutely brilliant. It's also got bench points lost which tracks how many points each manager has lost to the bench across the season. And another one that I absolutely love is the whatif tool. So tell us what the whatif tool is. >> Yeah, so that's another one of uh the popular features I think people love using. Um, basically it calculates what if I was to swap with someone else's schedule. Um, would I have would I have ranked or would I be in a different position? So, if I had someone else's schedule, would I be first, would I be second? And it does that with everyone and calculates your best swap. So, if who would I have swapped or who should I have swapped with and been highest ranking in my league right now? >> Brilliant stuff. Well, what we've done is we have taken all the data from your app and we've plugged it into one of our leagues, which is the FPL Draft Zone Championship. There are three leagues at the FPL Draft Zone and the Championship is the Middle League. It's got 10 managers in. It is a head-to-head format. So, let's first of all take a look at the league analytics page that pops up on the app when you load it up. The league analytics on the lefth hand side, if you're watching us on YouTube, has quick stats. So, it has the most FPL points in that league. So, the team top of the league, well, not necessarily top of the league, I suppose, but the team who's accured the most points, which in this case after 24 gameweeks is 1,152. It has the fewest FPL points. It has the total matches played and the point spread. And it also has little individual stats that give you bragging rights over your mate. So, the top gameweek score of the season so far, 75 points, which I'm proud to say was my team. Uh and the best win streak in the league, six wins on the spin and that goes to Liam Smith whose side is draft excluded and who are top of the table as you can see in the middle column. Current win streaks are also ranked. So I have a twoame win streak right now and that puts me top. And then on the right hand side is a little line graph which you can plot every single team into and that tells you week by week where you were in the league at any given week and plots out your entire season. So that is that's the the sort of the league analytics tool. This is something I absolutely love which is all leagues combined. Tell us what this is. >> Yeah, so this is on the website actually. So, this allows you if you're in multiple leagues, you can just input both all your leagues into your account and then you can combine them to see how you rank um throughout all your leagues and how everyone ranks in that sense. And it has the league name in them. And that's why you can see that there's different league names for everyone. >> Yeah. So, this is four different leagues. We've got the three FPL draft zone leagues and also one of my local leagues. And these are the top 10 total scores across those leagues. So shout outs to Tyler Keller, Liam Smith, and Tom Waldy who make up the top four. Dan Walker just missing out on the top four. He's in fifth. And George Stthopoulos is down in 10th. But very competitive when you look at that. That is like almost like the ultimate draft league, isn't it? It's fantastic idea. We've also got the best manager tool, which is another really interesting one. Obviously, you've got the league table, which is what it's all about, but this is how other metrics measure your teams. So, a reminder that in this league, Liam Smith is top, Mike Whitefield is second, and I am third. So, the total points are on the left hand column of the screen if you're watching this on YouTube. Liam's got 49 points, Mike's got 45, and I've got 42. But if you look at the goals on the right hand side of this screen in the third column, that tells you an awful lot about why Liam is top of the league because he's side has scored 223 goals. And that is miles clear of anyone else in this league. I'm down in sixth with 164 and Mike who's third has got 171. So, this is the sort of thing, David, where you sort of look at these stats almost through a different lens because you're looking at them and you're going, actually, that's where I'm failing. That's where I'm succeeding. And I think we've got more of that on the next page because in the assist ranking, if you look on the left hand side of this column, Mike, who's second in the league, is ninth for assists. And Liam, who's top, is down in sixth. Pretty crazy. The same could be said about clean sheets. Mike's got a pretty good defensive record. His title challenge is built on defense from the looks of it. And I'm down in ninth with just 101 clean sheets. And then saves. I'm up in second with 25. And Mike is down in 12th. And Liam is eighth. Bonus points. Liam is well clear and I am in third. And Mike Whitefield second in the league down in 64. So, what would you say when you're looking at these sort of metrics and you're looking at the differences? Do you as a manager, as a draft manager, look at these and go, "Okay, I need to get players in who are scoring more goals. I need to get players in who are scoring more bonus points." Do you look at them and do you use them for your own draft team and try and work out where it is you're going wrong? >> Yeah. No, that's exactly where I do use them actually. I look at them, you see a breakdown of where you're lacking, where you're not lacking, and I try to adjust it. So, if I'm if I'm really low in I guess um like like goals, then maybe I'm going to need to try to fix up my forwards, my mids, see maybe get more attacking mids um and and just try to fix that up because you can generally see a th a trend when you look at players that are top in the league and then when you're looking at yourself and try to improve your squad as much as you can. Um and the website has even more of a breakdown where you can see uh by position uh by by players and so on. Um, so I can look at my my defense and see how I rank defensively in my league versus maybe who's first defensively. Um, so use that always to help me pick up players or trade players throughout the league. >> I always thought defensively I was pretty solid, but ninth out of 10 for clean sheets, that is where I am going wrong in this league. It's also got a lovely head-to-head feature, which is a live head-to-head. So on a match day it will give you updates live as to what's happening. On the left hand side of the screen you can see that this is taken from gameweek 24 where in this league there were five matches. The average score across those five matches and 10 teams was 42 and a half points. And down at the bottom of the screen you can see the individual matchup. So that week I actually played Whitefield's Warriors and edged that one and the league leader Liam Smith beat Gab Gabrielle Blide House in a very highscoring 5751. But it also has top scorers for every game week as well which is another nice little chart that you can follow. And on this week it was Hugo Eat who came out on top alongside Casemiro with Florian Vvers Domanki and Kenati making up the top five. Tell us about the transfer analysis tool. >> Yeah. No. So, in my league, we have one person that pretty much dominates our transfer window every every week. Um, with a ton of trades in, backup trades, waiverss, and so on. Um, so the transfer tool is just a way of tracking it. Unfortunately, the Premier League app doesn't actually provide you any of that stuff. It shows you during the week of, and then they disappear. Um, so this is a way where you can track, see how many trades are happening, who's has the most trades in your league, and what kind of trades they're doing, and just keeps a record of them. And then that way you can actually look at analysis afterwards. Was this trade good? Was it bad? Would this trade um have cost me the match? Or did it did it cost me or did it not? Uh did it make me lose my matchup that week? Um so it's it's really cool stat that it helps and you can constantly see who's trading for what. And if you want to maybe look at the next week's matchup, I'm playing against someone else, you can look at it and see if they're more likely to make a trade or not based off their previous trades as well. So, in this league after 24 weeks, 601 transfers. Is that above average, below average, or about about average? What do we think? >> It looks like it's uh it's a high number there. I won't I won't lie for sure. But, uh every season has people that are trading constantly, but there's there's been higher I've seen, and there's been much lower, of course. >> Good to know. Uh you did mention there that you can track good transfers and bad transfers, and this is another bragging rights kind of feature. It lists the best trade of the season in your individual leagues and the worst trade of the season in your individual leagues. So in this league, Burke has the bragging rights because he traded out Meankovic in game week six and brought in Alderete of Sunderland, which gave him a plus 16 point swing. And Liam may be top of the league, but he had a stinker in gameweek 12, transferring out Marillo for Van Hec and costing himself 15 points in the process. So, another lovely little feature there that really does get you the sort of the adrenaline pumping when it comes to your rival managers. We talked a little bit earlier about unlucky analysis. We've got on screen what it is on the app then how it explains it, but do you want to just talk us through this again? >> Yeah, so pretty much this is the way that I calculate if you're lucky or unlucky. Um, so an unlucky loss, you scored above the median and you still lost or uh if you're lucky, you scored below the median and you won. And then we calculate something called a luck score.
